column4: Evidence_or_Fact
column5: Implication

column4: For ~1500 years, per-capita income stayed near ancient Rome levels.
column5: Arts existed historically in an economy without modern productivity pressures.

column4: 20th century per-capita income increased ~600–700%.
column5: Widening productivity gap increases financial pressure on live arts.

column3: Technological change enables new art forms
column4: ICT revolution expanded dissemination (film, digital media, streaming).
column5: Technology enhances reach but intensifies relative cost pressure for live arts.

column4: Wages rise with general economy; arts productivity fixed → rising relative costs.
column5: Structural earnings gap persists regardless of management efficiency.

column4: A string quartet today requires same labour as 1800.
column5: Live arts cannot benefit from tech-driven productivity improvements.

column4: Each new production has one-time creative/design/rehearsal costs.
column5: High fixed costs require subsidies

column4: Marginal cost of an extra attendee is low once production mounted.
column5: Encourages pricing models capturing consumer surplus.

column4: NPOs cannot distribute surplus → not profit maximizers.
column5: Allows quality-maximization but reduces efficiency incentives.

column4: Large orchestras = quality maximizers; smaller groups = audience maximizers.
column5: Different cost-risk profiles across organizations.

column4: Artists accept low pay to maintain quality.
column5: Keeps profit margins structurally low; encourages over-supply.

column4: Subscriptions purchased before product exists.
column5: Requires credibility; nonprofit status provides trust.

column4: Gov’t supports goods people under-consume.
column5: Justifies subsidies even when market demand low.

column4: Existence, option, bequest, prestige, cultural value.
column5: Supports case for public funding beyond ticket buyers.

column4: Taxpayers subsidize tickets mostly consumed by high-income households.
column5: Raises fairness concerns; arts audiences skew affluent.

column4: Each $1 subsidy displaces $0.10–$0.50 private giving.
column5: Public funding not fully additive; may weaken philanthropy.

column4: Including time cost → income elasticity >1.
column5: Arts function as luxury goods once full price considered.

column4: Price increases reduce attendance, especially among lower-education groups.
column5: Ticket policy shapes audience composition.

column4: Empirical results mixed for TV/other media as substitutes or complements.
column5: Effectiveness of digital strategy context-dependent.

column4: Education levels consistently correlated with attendance.
column5: Educational outreach has long-run impact.

column4: Childhood arts experiences strongly predict adult attendance.
column5: Investments in youth exposure yield generational benefits.

column4: Attendance influenced by friends/family and social norms.
column5: Peer-based marketing can be effective.

column4: Past attendance increases future attendance likelihood.
column5: Intro offers and low-barrier first experiences matter.

column4: Higher-education groups consume diverse culture; low-education groups consume less.
column5: Arts inclusion requires addressing cultural access barriers beyond price.

column4: Teens/young adults view ballet as boring, stuffy, elitist.
column5: Brand identity must counter perceived exclusivity.

column4: Behind-the-scenes video increased familiarity and reduced intimidation.
column5: Digital storytelling builds accessibility.

column4: Emotional, human, inclusive visuals attracted younger audiences.
column5: Brand tone and visuals shape belonging.

column4: Peer-group events foster belonging and reduce anxiety.
column5: Community-building is as important as price.

column4: Increased trial did not meaningfully increase subscriptions.
column5: Younger audiences resistant to long-commitment models.

column4: Austin Wranglers found youth leagues did not convert to spectators.
column5: Participatory programs do not automatically produce ticket buyers.

column4: Participation must be tied to spectating intentionally.
column5: Arts schools and community programs must create bridges to mainstage.

column4: Revenue +7% in some cases vs static pricing.
column5: Dynamic pricing increases expected revenue under constraints.

column4: Dynamic pricing ~28% better in worst-case revenue (CVaR 5%).
column5: Useful for demand uncertainty and tight capacity.

column4: Lower admin/menu costs; less brand risk.
column5: May be preferable when demand uncertain but capacity ample.

column4: Mixed evidence: sometimes substitute, sometimes complement.
column5: Media strategy must be intentional

column4: PNB video content increased youth attendance.
column5: Digital-first engagement required for young demographics.

column4: Performing arts require payment and presence → not pure public goods.
column5: Supports hybrid funding models with donations + subsidy.

column4: Donations often correlate with enjoyment and perceived quality.
column5: Quality investments can raise giving more than ticket revenues.

column4: Different political parties shift arts policy unpredictably.
column5: Long-term planning harder for arts organizations.

column4: Value unknown until product released; historical analogies used.
column5: Risk diversification needed via repertory mix.

column4: Creative development costs unrecoverable if audience weak.
column5: Programming choices must balance risk vs artistic goals.

column4: Consumers may be short-sighted about cultural value.
column5: Gov’t interventions justified under welfare theory.

column4: Subsidies may reduce consumer sovereignty but increase cultural access.
column5: Tension between efficiency and equity.

column4: NPO status signals high-quality intent and non-exploitation.
column5: Enables advance sales models.

column4: Tech enabled arts to reach mass audiences via media.
column5: Increases competition for attention.

column3: Photography displaced portraiture; tech repeatedly disrupts art forms.
column4: Artistic labour markets vulnerable to shifts.

column4: Education > income in predicting attendance.
column5: Audience diversification requires addressing cultural capital

column4: Youth see ballet as elite and inaccessible.
column5: Brand and environment redesign essential.

column4: Cost disease + sunk costs → permanent gap.
column5: Long-term viability requires reliable subsidy/philanthropy.

column4: Participation doesn’t guarantee spectating.
column5: Programs need built-in conversion mechanisms.
